awd_titl_txt: Acquisition of a pXRF and pLIBS Instrument Suite for Geochemistry Research in the Urban Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Portable X-ray fluorescence (pXRF) and portable laser induced breakdown spectroscopy (pLIBS) instruments will be used in Geochemistry research to determine the elemental compositions of soils, sediments, and other environmental media in natural, urban, and human-impacted environments. Rutgers University-Newark is a Hispanic Serving Institution, and supported projects and activities will engage students from diverse backgrounds and foster their participation in place-based research and education. The instruments will be accessible to undergraduate researchers and graduate students, including students participating in NSF-sponsored programs to broaden participation in the Geosciences. Use of the instruments in the field and laboratory will be included in course modules and class projects to enrich the educational experience of students in relevant courses. Ease of use and instrument portability will facilitate inclusion in community- based projects that involve the public in STEM research, and outreach initiatives for education and engagement of K-12 students.

Acquisition of portable X-ray fluorescence (pXRF) and portable laser induced breakdown spectroscopy (pLIBS) instruments will enhance Geochemistry research by providing in-field non- destructive analysis of elemental concentrations in natural, urban and human-impacted environments. The instrument suite enables quantitative and qualitative analysis of a wide range of elements, including light elements such as carbon. Instrument capabilities will be coupled with complementary laboratory-based and advanced analytical techniques for elemental analysis, speciation, and matrix determination. The pXRF/pLIBS instrument suite will be used in Geochemistry research for in-situ and in-field analyses of heavy metals, major elements and nutrient elements in soils and sediments. Projects to be supported integrate research with education and community engagement, and include heavy metal spatial distribution and speciation in Newark, New Jersey soils; the geochemistry of legacy pollutants in sediments of the New Jersey Meadowlands; and micronutrient and carbon cycling in agricultural soils. Activities and projects will prioritize training of undergraduate researchers and graduate students through local and international research; in courses and as part of a globalized curriculum; and in NSF-sponsored programs that support participation of groups underrepresented in the Geosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A grant was awarded to a team in the Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences (DEES) at Rutgers University, Newark (RU-N) to acquire portable X-ray fluorescence (pXRF) and portable laser induced breakdown spectroscopy (pLIBS) instruments for elemental analysis of environmental samples. The instrument suite purchased was a SciAps ONE BOX system consisting of a X-505 Soil XRF Analyzer and a SciAps Z-903 GeoChem LIBS Analyzer, which combined covers most elements on the periodic table. The instrument suite facilitated more effective in-field analysis, and sample selection for laboratory-based and advanced analyses. Research projects engaged graduate and undergraduate students traditionally underrepresented in STEM disciplines by leveraging other NSF programs, and fostered place-based and community-engaged research projects and outreach activities. Examples of projects include evaluation of soils with different land use types including public parks and urban gardens in the city of Newark. 

Heavy Metals in Urban Park Soils A graduate student project studied high contact soils in Newark public parks, which are in proximity to transportation routes and industrial zones. Surface soils throughout the parks were analyzed by pXRF which provided immediately available data regarding the elemental composition and concentrations of heavy metals in the soils. Commonly detected metals included arsenic and lead. The data was used to select soils with elevated concentrations of metals such as arsenic and lead for sampling and in-lab analysis to determine speciation, bioavailability and bioaccessibility. The graduate student leading the project is compiling the data and results for publication and as a chapter of the PhD dissertation and is supported by an NSF RISE Cultural Transformation in the Geoscience Community (CTGC) grant. During this project the graduate student mentored 3 undergraduates supported through this grant and by the NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) and the NSF Garden State LSAMP (GSLSAMP) programs.

 

Soil Amendments in Urban Gardens A NSF REU undergraduate student conducted a summer research project to evaluate the effect of geologic amendments on the carbon and nutrient content of imported soils used in an urban garden in Newark. This research required use of the pLIBS and pXRF instruments in the field and the lab to determine the composition of the soil, the amendments and mixed soil-amendment samples. The pXRF provided data on the trace and micronutrient metal content and the pLIBS instrument provided data on the nutrient element composition of the samples and mixtures (Figure 1). The research was continued in the academic year through support from the NSF GSLSAMP program and involved characterizing compost generated at an urban garden hosted by a local high school and evaluating the impact of this amendment on the carbon and nutrient profiles of the garden soils.

NewGeo Project The NSF CTGC Newark Geoscience Ecosystem (NewGeo) is an experiential learning network, connecting academic and non-academic institutions in the city of Newark with the common goal of addressing local and global urban environmental, climate, and geo-challenges through workforce development. As part of NewGeo, graduate students leverage their academic preparation and build career skills through place-based experiential learning experiences in collaboration with NewGeo community partners. Six graduate students are currently participating in co-created research projects with community organizations centered issues of environmental concern to the local community. These research projects span analysis of soils, water and air in the city and several of the projects involve use of the pXRF and pLIBS suite both in the field and the lab.

Outreach Activities

Data and findings from pXRF analysis of Newark soils was the focus of an activity for Newark youth participating in a Summer Youth Climate Justice Ambassador Program. The PI discussed metals in urban soils in Newark and the implications for climate, environment and human health, and a graduate student demonstrated use of the pXRF on local park samples. Several outreach activities took place in Newark's urban gardens and engaged garden managers and volunteers, K-12 students and the public (Figure 2). Garden managers requested surveys of metal profiles in their soils to determine environmental risk. The pXRF was used to analyze soils in raised beds and other planted and unplanted areas. Newark youth participating in a sustainability camp in a local garden brought soils from their homes to determine whether they could plant crops. Both undergraduate and graduate researchers participated in these activities and also discussed the results from their own research studies.

In Summary, the pXRF/pLIBS instrument suite was used for field and laboratory analyses of heavy metals, major elements and nutrient elements in soils and sediments. Supported projects integrated research with community-engagement, and prioritized training of undergraduate and graduate researchers, including those from traditionally underrepresented groups, and leveraged other NSF programs. The instrument suite was demonstrated in both formal and informal settings for K-12 students and members of the public, broadening the reach of geochemistry research, and highlighting the societal relevance and public impact of the discipline.
